Wat doet een architect?

Een architect ontwerpt gebouwen en ruimtes, bewaakt functionaliteit en esthetiek, en zorgt voor naleving van bouwregels. Daarnaast adviseert hij of zij over materialen, lichtinval en energieprestaties.

Wanneer heb je een architect nodig?

Een architect is essentieel bij nieuwbouw, uitbreidingen, grote renovaties en vergunningsaanvragen. Dit voorkomt ontwerp­fouten en zorgt voor een soepel verloop richting uitvoering.

Rol tijdens de uitvoering?

Architecten kunnen toezicht houden op de bouw, controleren of alles volgens plan verloopt en adviseren bij onverwachte situaties.

What does an architect do?

An architect plays a central role in shaping buildings and spaces that are functional, visually appealing, and compliant with all legal requirements. Their work goes far beyond creating drawings; they translate ideas, needs, and constraints into practical and well-considered designs. An architect carefully balances aesthetics, usability, budget, and technical feasibility throughout the design process. Key responsibilities include:
  • Designing floor plans, elevations, and technical drawings
  • Creating efficient spatial layouts that suit the user’s needs
  • Ensuring compliance with building codes, zoning rules, and safety regulations
  • Advising on materials, construction methods, and sustainability options
In addition, architects consider factors such as daylight, ventilation, acoustics, and energy efficiency to create comfortable and future-proof spaces. They often collaborate with engineers, contractors, and local authorities to ensure the design can be executed smoothly. By combining creativity with technical expertise, an architect helps avoid costly mistakes and ensures that a project is both visually strong and technically sound.

When do you need an architect?

You typically need an architect when a project involves structural changes, complex design decisions, or legal approval requirements. Architects are especially valuable when projects go beyond minor adjustments and require professional planning, coordination, and documentation.
  • An architect is commonly required for:
  • New residential or commercial construction
  • Home extensions or major structural modifications
  • Large-scale renovations or restorations
  • Permit and zoning applications with local authorities
In many regions, architectural drawings are mandatory for building permits. Engaging an architect early in the process helps identify potential design or regulatory issues before construction begins. This proactive approach reduces delays, prevents costly revisions, and ensures a smoother approval process. Even when an architect is not legally required, their expertise adds significant value by improving design quality, optimizing space usage, and aligning the project with your budget and long-term goals.

Role during the construction phase:

During the construction phase, an architect can act as a key point of oversight to ensure the project is built exactly as designed. Their involvement helps maintain quality, manage risks, and address challenges that may arise on site.
  • Typical responsibilities during execution include:
  • Monitoring construction progress and quality
  • Verifying that work follows approved drawings and specifications
  • Coordinating with contractors and consultants
  • Advising on solutions when unexpected issues occur
Architects serve as an objective professional who represents the client’s interests, helping to prevent misinterpretations or shortcuts during construction. When changes are necessary, they can assess the impact on design, cost, and planning compliance. This guidance improves reliability, reduces errors, and increases overall build quality. As a result, architectural supervision often leads to better outcomes, fewer disputes, and a more controlled and predictable construction process.
